column4: Hello, I volunteer as a sysadmin for a small private school. I'm looking for a way to setup remote access for teachers and students. Any suggestions?
vinagre / vino-server - these are VNC-based "remote desktop sharing" software for Linux/Ubuntu
either that or you can use XDCMP, but that requires you to then use an X server on the client and if the client is Windows, that's not super easy - although can be done free of cost
(can you tell I volunteer as computer admin for a small private school?)
I
I've only recently setup a linux server for the computer lab. Its running LTSP and the workstations are using pxe. I set it up over the weekend.
edubuntu?
join #edubuntu or #ltsp as well if you've got questions around those... might get more specific answers than here which is general desktop support
What I'm really looking for is vpn access for teachers and home directory access for students.

Ah!  Different beast altogether :) If you are running from a mixed (linux/windows) set of clients, PPTP is probably the easiest and best vpn for you to set up.  Check out  pptpd (PoPToP Point to Point Tunneling Server)
Thanks for the info.

I actually use my school's Win2k3 server to act as radius server and run VPN from that, but can be done many different ways, including as I just suggested having the VPN server be linux running PPTP server software
are you supporting a heterogeneous school network or are all the computers using Linux?
Its mixed right now. The computer lab was the first of many steps to migrate away from Windows.
do you have a domain controller?
Yes. W2k3. Its overburdened. Its the PDC, http, dns, gateway and file server right now.

as part of a "gentle" migration away from Windows, I'd suggest looking at Likewise Open version 5 (aptitude search likewise-open) to allow the linux machines to authenticate against the Windows Domain
I had stumbled across that over the weekend.
it works well, and I've got it working for me (at work I am part of the domain with my linux laptop)
I'd recommend replacing the PDC with a linux firewall as a first step to overall network changes.  Have it connect to the internet, and allow the PDC to do everything else it currently does
if the PDC HTTP server is external as well as internal, you then need some firewall rules to do port forwarding, but that is easy.
